posts.text: yes

pushed the change.  I also added the oauth 2.0 feature to the apps (I created a second app for production) with the same callback url’s we entered into github.  It gave me an auth_code_generator_url template which I added as another variable (CS_API_JIRA_AUTH_CODE_GEN_TEMPLATE).
Make sure you update your secrets (*dt-update-secrets*), pull the latest on development and reload your sandbox
`env|grep JIRA` to verify
Finally, I added all the required fields for both apps so now it’s up to the atlassian guys to get them published. There are two apps under my atlassian account.

```
development: ZA2TOONdGfnQh5o5JtlmUIm33NM7k1mz
production: uO25m5LXVStXYvwucx3ah4875p4y0XrX
```

Lets plan on doing an extension release tomorrow. There's a decent amount of stuff that's ready to go out. Friday isn't really an option because the NY office will be doing the second half of our move and then a holiday lunch/drinking.

FYI to all, the TC vscode dev extension build is configured to created assets for *develop* as well as any branch that begins with *feature/*.  The *develop* asset is saved on our asset server, the other build assets are available from the TC web site (https://tc.codestream.us/)

branch has been renamed.  You can grab the asset for it from this page:
http://tc.codestream.us/project.html?projectId=VscodeCodestream&tab=projectOverview

does anyone know if there’s something weird with VS Code and string searches across a repo? i’ve got a change i need to make that is dependent on finding a certain string, and VS Code just will not show me all the instances of that string in a search … it’s driving me crazy because i keep finding new instances that the search didn’t find originally
there's the file/search exclude patterns in settings...
no it’s definitely not that
@Akonwi you’ll be happy to know i resorted to atom to do it :confused:
i was thinking about saying something
i’ve had this problem before, i think there’s a vs code bug … it doesn’t happen all the time but when it does it seems to “persist” (like searching over and over doesn’t solve it)
it’s a case-sensitive search so that might have something to do with it
is it just a simple search? or regex? single word or something that could span line breaks?
@jj when you changed `inline` to `feature/inline` did you rename the branch or just create a new one?
No standup for me as I am flying.
he did a rename
damn -- would have expected a better outcome then

If you have been using the `inline` branches, you will likely need to do the following to resync them:
```
git branch -m inline feature/inline
git branch -u origin/feature/inline feature/inline
```
you may also want to do a `git fetch -p` to prune any old remote branches

I did
```
git fetch origin
git checkout old-name
git branch -m new-name
git push origin :old-name new-name
git push origin -u new-name
```
I pruned when I was done, but I didn’t need to in this repo

I just remembered from a stand-up 2+ weeks ago, that someone was asking how we handle static image serving.  We have a repo that gets copied to an S3 bucket which is the origin for an AWS CloudFront distribution (CDN).
